executiveSummary.problemStatement: Organizations deploying AI agents face critical governance challenges: no standardized way to cryptographically identify AI agents, no mechanism to verify agent capabilities and security posture before granting access, agents often store API keys and OAuth tokens directly creating security risks, limited visibility into what agents access and on whose behalf, and no centralized management of expensive LLM API usage across agents.
executiveSummary.proposedSolution: The Agent and MCP Control Plane provides centralized governance infrastructure for AI agent and MCP server ecosystems, implementing cryptographic identity via SPIFFE/SPIRE, trust attestation via Know Your Agent (KYA) certification, just-in-time credential injection via a governance proxy, comprehensive audit logging of all agent and MCP server actions, and LLM usage management with model-level policies and cost tracking.
expectedOutcomes: 100% of agents have cryptographically verifiable SPIFFE IDs
Zero API keys stored in agent code or configuration
100% of API calls logged with full identity context
Mean time to revoke access under 1 minute
100% LLM cost attribution to agent and user
executiveSummary.targetAudience: Organizations deploying AI agents requiring enterprise-grade governance, identity, and security
executiveSummary.valueProposition: End-to-end agent identity, attestation, credential injection, and observability in a unified control plane - addressing a market gap where no existing solution provides this combination

businessObjectives.description: Capture leadership position in the $9-10B agent governance market by 2030
businessObjectives.rationale: AI Agents market growing at 46.3% CAGR with significant governance gaps

businessObjectives.description: Achieve $250M ARR by Year 5 through enterprise customer acquisition
businessObjectives.rationale: Conservative market capture of 1,000+ enterprise customers

businessObjectives.description: Differentiate from cloud IAM, zero trust, and API gateway competitors
businessObjectives.rationale: No existing solution provides agent-native identity and governance

productGoals.description: Implement zero-trust agent identity where every agent has a cryptographically verifiable identity
Achieve credential isolation where agents never possess API keys or OAuth tokens
Enable delegated access with scoped, time-limited user authorization to agents
Provide full auditability with every credential access logged with agent and user context
productGoals.rationale: Required for compliance and incident response

productGoals.description: Implement cost governance with centralized control over LLM API usage and costs
productGoals.rationale: LLM costs are significant and need attribution

successMetrics.name: Agent Identity Coverage
successMetrics.description: Percentage of agents with SPIFFE IDs
successMetrics.measurementMethod: SPIRE registration entries / total registered agents

successMetrics.name: Credential Exposure
successMetrics.description: API keys stored in agent code or configuration

successMetrics.name: Audit Completeness
successMetrics.description: Percentage of API calls logged with full identity context

successMetrics.name: Mean Time to Revoke
successMetrics.description: Time to revoke agent access after decision

successMetrics.name: LLM Cost Attribution
successMetrics.description: Percentage of LLM costs attributed to agent and user

personas.name: End-User
personas.description: Individuals who authorize agents and MCP servers to act on their behalf via ID-JAG delegation
goals: Find and use trusted AI agents safely
Grant limited, time-bound access to personal accounts
painPoints: Cannot verify if an agent is trustworthy
No control over what agents access
Cannot see what agents did on their behalf
Difficult to revoke access across multiple services
behaviors: Connects multiple SaaS accounts (Google, Salesforce, etc.)
Delegates specific tasks to AI agents

personas.name: Agent Creator
personas.description: Developers who build and deploy AI agents; submit agents for KYA attestation
goals: Access user data securely on their behalf
painPoints: No standard identity framework for agents
behaviors: Develops AI agents using various frameworks

personas.name: MCP Server Creator
personas.description: Developers who build MCP servers that connect to external services; submit MCP servers for KYA attestation
goals: Register MCP servers with proper identity
Control which agents can invoke the MCP server
behaviors: Builds tool providers for AI agents

personas.name: Platform Administrator
personas.description: Teams managing the agent governance infrastructure; review KYA attestation submissions
goals: Control LLM model access and costs

personas.name: Security/Compliance
personas.description: Teams requiring audit trails and policy enforcement; manage KYA attestation policies

userStories.title: Browse Agent Catalog
userStories.iWant: to browse a catalog of verified AI agents
userStories.soThat: I can find agents that meet my needs

acceptanceCriteria.description: User can view list of agents with trust ratings
acceptanceCriteria.given: User is logged into the portal
acceptanceCriteria.then: User sees list of agents with KYA trust ratings displayed

userStories.title: View KYA Attestation
userStories.iWant: to view an agent's KYA attestation before granting access
userStories.soThat: I can make informed trust decisions

acceptanceCriteria.description: User can view detailed attestation information
acceptanceCriteria.given: User is viewing an agent in the catalog
acceptanceCriteria.then: User sees KYA attestation details including trust level and capabilities

userStories.title: Grant Scoped Delegation
userStories.iWant: to grant an agent access to my Google Drive with read-only scope
userStories.soThat: the agent can search my documents without modifying them

acceptanceCriteria.description: User can select specific scopes when granting access
acceptanceCriteria.given: User is granting delegation to an agent
acceptanceCriteria.then: Delegation is created with only the selected scopes

userStories.title: Time-Limited Access
userStories.iWant: to set a 24-hour expiry on agent access

acceptanceCriteria.description: User can set delegation expiry time

userStories.title: Immediate Revocation
userStories.iWant: to revoke an agent's access immediately
userStories.soThat: I can respond to suspicious behavior

acceptanceCriteria.description: Revocation takes effect within 1 minute
acceptanceCriteria.given: User has an active delegation to an agent
acceptanceCriteria.then: Agent access is terminated within 1 minute

userStories.title: View Agent Actions
userStories.iWant: to view what actions an agent performed on my behalf

acceptanceCriteria.description: User can view audit history
acceptanceCriteria.then: User sees chronological list of agent actions

userStories.title: Register Agent
userStories.iWant: to register my agent with its SPIFFE ID
userStories.soThat: it can be discovered and governed

acceptanceCriteria.description: Agent can be registered with SPIFFE ID
acceptanceCriteria.given: Agent creator is logged into portal
acceptanceCriteria.when: Creator registers agent with metadata and SPIFFE ID
acceptanceCriteria.then: Agent is registered and can receive SVIDs

userStories.title: Submit for KYA Review
userStories.iWant: to submit my agent for KYA review
userStories.soThat: it can receive a trust attestation

acceptanceCriteria.description: Agent can be submitted for attestation review

userStories.title: Configure LLM Policies
userStories.iWant: to configure which LLM models each agent can use
userStories.soThat: I can control costs and capabilities

acceptanceCriteria.description: Admin can set model-level access policies
acceptanceCriteria.when: Admin configures model access for an agent
acceptanceCriteria.then: Agent can only use allowed models

userStories.title: Set LLM Budget Limits
userStories.iWant: to set monthly LLM budget limits per agent

acceptanceCriteria.description: Budget limits are enforced
acceptanceCriteria.given: Admin has set budget limit for agent
acceptanceCriteria.then: Agent is rate limited or blocked

userStories.title: Emergency Revocation
userStories.iWant: to revoke all delegations for a compromised agent
userStories.soThat: I can respond to incidents quickly

acceptanceCriteria.description: Bulk revocation works immediately
acceptanceCriteria.then: All delegations are invalidated and proxy rejects all requests

phases.name: Foundation
goals: Establish core identity infrastructure with SPIFFE/SPIRE
Deploy Governance Proxy with credential injection
Launch Portal for all persona types

deliverables.title: SPIRE Server Deployment
deliverables.description: SPIRE server with Docker and Kubernetes selectors

deliverables.title: Governance Proxy MVP
deliverables.description: mTLS validation, credential injection, audit logging

deliverables.title: Secrets Vault
deliverables.description: HSM-backed storage for OAuth tokens, LLM keys, tool keys

deliverables.title: Portal - End-User Features
deliverables.description: Agent catalog, delegation management, account connection

successCriteria: 100% of registered agents have SPIFFE IDs
All personas can complete core workflows

phases.name: Scale & Compliance
goals: Prepare for SOC 2 Type I certification

deliverables.title: LLM Budget Management
deliverables.description: Budget limits, alerts, enforcement per agent/org

deliverables.title: Usage Analytics Dashboard

assumptions.description: Organizations will adopt SPIFFE/SPIRE as the agent identity standard
assumptions.rationale: SPIFFE is the leading workload identity standard

assumptions.description: LLM providers will maintain stable APIs
assumptions.rationale: Anthropic, OpenAI have stable production APIs
assumptions.risk: Breaking API changes require proxy updates

assumptions.rationale: Market research shows SOC 2 as enterprise gate

constraints.description: Must comply with GDPR for EU users
constraints.impact: Data residency requirements, right to deletion

constraints.description: SOC 2 Type II requires 6+ months of evidence
constraints.mitigation: Start evidence collection early in Phase 1

dependencies.name: SPIFFE/SPIRE Project
dependencies.description: Dependency on SPIFFE/SPIRE for workload identity

dependencies.name: LLM Provider APIs
dependencies.description: Dependency on Anthropic, OpenAI, Google AI APIs

outOfScope: Agent cognition/reasoning (handled by agent frameworks like LangChain, AutoGen)

technicalArchitecture.overview: The architecture follows the industry-standard separation of control plane and data plane. The Control Plane handles configuration, policy, and identity issuance (SPIRE Server, Policy Store, Credential Vault). The Data Plane handles request processing and policy enforcement (Governance Gateway, SPIRE Agent). This pattern follows Istio, Kubernetes, and Consul architectures.

integrationPoints.name: OAuth Providers
integrationPoints.description: User account connection (Google, Salesforce, GitHub, Microsoft 365)

integrationPoints.name: LLM Providers
integrationPoints.description: Proxied LLM access (Anthropic, OpenAI, Google AI, Azure OpenAI)

database.name: PostgreSQL
database.purpose: Primary data store with row-level security

risks.description: Compromised agent binary performing unauthorized actions
Delegation scope escalation granting excess permissions

risks.mitigation: HSM backing, encryption at rest, access logging

risks.description: Governance Proxy bypass enabling direct API access
risks.mitigation: Network policies, no credentials in agents

risks.description: Insider admin abuse leading to data exfiltration
risks.mitigation: Audit logging, separation of duties, MFA

risks.description: Competing standard emerges for agent identity
risks.mitigation: Active participation in SPIFFE community, extensible architecture

glossary.definition: Secure Production Identity Framework for Everyone - a set of standards for identifying and securing communications between services
SPIFFE Runtime Environment - the reference implementation of SPIFFE
SPIFFE Verifiable Identity Document - an X.509 certificate that encodes a SPIFFE ID
Know Your Agent - attestation framework for verifying AI agent trustworthiness, capabilities, and security posture
User authorization for an agent to act on their behalf with specific scopes and time limits
Mutual TLS - both client and server present certificates for authentication
Server-Sent Events - streaming protocol used for LLM responses
Model Context Protocol - protocol for connecting AI agents to external tools and services
Infrastructure components responsible for configuration, policy, and identity issuance
Infrastructure components responsible for request processing and policy enforcement
